section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build math background, play a counting game, and introduce vocabulary (yawn, snoring).
Start Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What is one thing Lucy does during the day?
Read interactively for meaning and enjoyment, pausing to practice counting.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that items and amounts can be counted; Recite number words from 1 to 30 in order.
Describe the passing of time.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Make connections between words and real life; Use subject-verb agreement, plurals, past tense, pronouns, and possessives.
Use complete sentences of four or more words; Use increasingly complex sentence structures.
Recognize at least 20 letter sounds.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children search the room for a specific number of objects or an object with a specific number of parts.
Guide children to describe the object using complete sentences.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do during the day and at night?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What book did you choose? What is this book about?
What does it look like when someone yawns? Can you show me?
Can you count from 1–30?
Write about something you do at night, but not during the day.
What materials did you use? Why did you choose those? How did you use them?
What sounds do you hear in the word yawn? Can you write or trace those letters?
What can you build using only three blocks?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder develop working memory and introduce vocabulary (memory, remember).
Start Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Twenty Yawns .
Read closely to notice how the characters use memory and to review counting.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that items and amounts can be counted.
Describe the passing of time.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Recognize at least 20 letter sounds.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Make connections between words and real life; Use subject-verb agreement, plurals, past tense, pronouns, and possessives.
Use complete sentences of four or more words; Use increasingly complex sentence structures.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Count a certain number of Connecting Cubes and then place them “behind the curtain.”
Guide children to remember how many cubes were counted, and count the same amount.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do during the day and at night?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What book did you choose? Does it take place during the day or at night?
Show what it feels like to be outside on a sunny day.
What changes happen when day turns into night?
Write about playing outside on a sunny day.
Can you draw, paint, or sculpt something you might see on a sunny day?
Look at all of these letters! Do you remember what sounds they all make?
Can you pretend to build a sandcastle using blocks? How many blocks will you use?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Twenty Yawns by Jane Smiley, illustrated by Lauren Castillo .Text copyright © 2016 by Jane Smiley. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Lauren Castillo. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Amazon Publishing. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share a time measurement strategy, play a time game, and introduce vocabulary (long).
Start Story Time by rereading Twenty Yawns and asking, Why does Lucy bring her stuffed animals to bed?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review the passing of time.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that items and amounts can be counted.
Describe the passing of time.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Recognize at least 20 letter sounds.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Make connections between words and real life.
Use subject-verb agreement, plurals, past tense, pronouns, and possessives.
Use complete sentences of four or more words; Use increasingly complex sentence structures.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children determine whether an activity takes a long time or short time.
Guide children to discuss their reasoning using complete sentences.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do during the day and at night?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What parts of the story happen during the day? At night? How do you know?
Pretend you’re cooking in the kitchen at night. Is it different than during the day? Why?
Can you draw the moon in the night sky? How does it look?
How is a walk outside different at night than during the day?
Can you draw, paint, or sculpt something you use at night?
What sounds do you hear in the word long? Can you write the word?
Why is it easier to build outside during the day than at night?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Twenty Yawns by Jane Smiley, illustrated by Lauren Castillo .Text copyright © 2016 by Jane Smiley. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Lauren Castillo. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Amazon Publishing.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Daytime/Nighttime

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to discuss day and night, play a time game, and introduce vocabulary (mountains, country).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Twenty Yawns and Daytime/Nighttime .
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question: What do we do during the day and at night?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that items and amounts can be counted.
Describe the passing of time.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Recognize at least 20 letter sounds.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Make connections between words and real life; Use subject-verb agreement, plurals, past tense, pronouns, and possessives.
Use complete sentences of four or more words; Use increasingly complex sentence structures.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to differentiate between day and night.
Guide children to identify activities that occur during the day and at night.
Guide children to count.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do during the day and at night?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What do you think about that book? What was the best part?
How would you act differently if you were doing the same thing at night?
Which of these groups has more?
What will you write first? Why are you planning to write about that?
Can you draw, paint, or sculpt something you see at night? How would you compare it to something you see during the day?
What sounds do you hear in the word day? Can you write some of those letters?
Can you build something special that you would only use at night?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Twenty Yawns by Jane Smiley, illustrated by Lauren Castillo .Text copyright © 2016 by Jane Smiley. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Lauren Castillo. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Amazon Publishing.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to connect to language and discuss day and night, engage children with movement, and play a counting game.
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, What is your favorite thing to do during the day?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and to review measurement.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that items and amounts can be counted; Recite number words from 1 to 30 in order.
Describe the passing of time.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Make connections between words and real life; Use subject-verb agreement, plurals, past tense, pronouns, and possessives.
Use complete sentences of four or more words; Use increasingly complex sentence structures.
Recognize at least 20 letter sounds.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to the prompt: Which do you like more: day or night? Why?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing for display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do during the day and at night?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What kind of book do you want to read next?
Pretend that you are going on a nighttime adventure. What should you wear? What should you bring?
Use Pattern Blocks to create the sun in the sky.
Can you write about which you like more, day or night, and why?
Think about what your home looks like at night and draw a picture of it.
Can you spell sun or moon with these letters? What sounds do you hear?
Count out 10 blocks. Can you use just these blocks to build one short building and one tall building? Let’s see!

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Know that objects, or parts of an object, can be counted.
Use words to rote count from 1 to 30.
Use language to describe the passing of time.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity.
Use plurals, past tense, pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Recognize at least 20 distinct letter sounds.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
